Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemomechanical imaging and engineering of single cell phenotype

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Krystyn J. VanVliet
0644846

The overall objective of this research is to address an unresolved bioengineering challenge: Can we engineer cell phenotype to human advantage through identification, imaging, and control of interactions between the dynamic cell surface and adjacent material environment? This question is central to synthesis of functional tissue in vitro and in vivo. Stem and progenitor cells, defined in part by the ability to adopt several distinct phenotypes under environmental cues, are particularly advantageous targets of this engineered function. Current limitations are due in part to our poor understanding of the general mechanisms by which cells respond dynamically to the environment. The capacity to assess cell phenotype through cell surface characteristics is critical to the engineering of environments that will guide cell function, particularly in mechanically responsive systems such as the vasculature. Thus, the objective of this research is to develop a chemomechanical approach to map the real-time changes in the surface of individual (1) vascular endothelial and (2) adult bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells using an advanced technique of scanning probe microscopy, termed functionalized force imaging (FFI). Sequential image acquisition will enable real-time, in vitro analysis of ligand-binding kinetics and cell response. The capacity to identify and quantify in real-time the molecular basis of cell surface environment interaction mechanisms within individual living cells will provide a new means by which cells present in low frequency can be identified, isolated, and analyzed in response to environmental stimuli. The educational and societal goals of this proposal are integrated within the proposed research methods and applications. The PI will train future researchers by developing new undergraduate laboratory modules and actively participating outreach programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to demonstrate how the tiny mechanical forces that are required to pull two molecules apart can be used to image the location of those chemical features on living cells. Our team exceeded our project goals to advance this frontier of knowledge, developing both new experiments and computational models for “seeing by feeling” on the cell surface. Figure 1 illustrates this capacity, imaging the number of a specific type of growth factor receptor (nanoscale proteins) on the outer surface of endothelial cells that line blood vessels.

Intellectual merit of this project pivoted on our hypothesis and successful demonstration that measurement of the picoNewton-scale forces used to separate molecular pairs could be used to quantify their location, and also to determine the binding kinetics and cell responses to new cues. In accomplishing this goal, we also discovered that cells could exert measurable force on our instrument through their own molecular networks, establishing a two-way street of exerting molecular scale forces on cells and also measuring the forces exerted by the cells’ internal machinery. Broader impact of this project included training of four engineering Ph.D. students, each entering the workforce with interdisciplinary skills that s/he has found invaluable in selected careers of physician, patent attorney, community health research, and biotech industry. Additional impact also included mentorship of diverse undergraduates who assisted in experiments and continued their interdisciplinary graduate-level educations, and our transfer of these approaches to several groups throughout the world including universities and research hospitals.

Why would we want to measure such small forces on cells? First, there existed few means to measure binding interactions between transmembrane proteins (those key receptors that bind biochemical molecules including medicines) in living cells. Transmembrane proteins are difficult to separate intact from living cells, so prior approaches offered only a poor approximation of how the receptors might appear or move around on an actual, living cell surface. Second, there existed few means to measure the cell’s own generation of mechanical forces, through engagement of those biochemical receptors in its cell membrane, with molecular-scale spatial and temporal resolution. Our nanomechanical approach to measure and image biochemical interactions with mechanical forces, coupled with our computational models ranging from atomistic to cellular levels, helped us to answer complex questions all related by a common focus on angiogenesis, which requires vascular endothelial cells to increase in number and migrate to extend new blood vessel sprouts.

This project resulted in several key outcomes:

  1. Chemomechanical imaging validation. We demonstrated a new approach to imaging molecular receptors on living biological cells, using molecules that bound specifically to those receptors to interrogate the cell surface. This method quantified both position and binding kinetics of those molecular pairs, using picoNewton scale unbinding forces between the living cell and an atomic force microscope cantilever functionalized with a molecular binding partner for that receptor (e.g., an antibody or ligand). We demonstrated this experimental capacity on vascular endothelial cells, both for a known growth factor receptor key to angiogenesis (blood vessel sprouting) and for a novel anti-angiogenic peptide (potential anti-cancer therapy) for which the cell binding target was not yet established (Fig. 2).
  2. Unbinding force model correction. We used a sophisticated load-displacement instrument to measure these intermolecular forces and create images and kinetic quantification: an atomic force microscope. Importantly, we used experiments and models to show that the stiffness of the AFM cantilever directly affected the measured unbinding forces and inferred binding kinetics. Through our molecular dynamics simulations of this experiment (Fig. 3), we established recognition of and correction of that potential measurement inaccuracy in this and several other advanced instrumentation approaches, which could otherwise affect drug dosages. We also described how this chemomechanical coupling could be used for advantage for design of drug-delivery-devices with material stiffness selected to maximize binding time to the cell surface target.
  3. Prediction and validation of vascular endothelial cell migration in wound and tumor environments. Building on the experimental and computational methods to measure ligand-receptor binding kinetics on living cells, we resolved an outstanding question in whether and how acidic pH of wounds and tumors affects vascular endothelial cells. Our chemomechanical experiments and molecular- to whole-cell simulations (Fig. 4) showed that acidic pH promotes activation of integrin receptors, which can in turn promote vascular cell migration toward acidic regions such as wounds or tumors.
  4. Demonstration that mechanical forces exerted by one cell type can promote biological processes in adjacent cell types. We used the same force-displacement instrument to quantify the mechanical strains exerted by pericytes, cells that encircle small and new blood vessels (Fig. 5). Important follow-up extensions of that work with one of the students initially trained in this project demonstrated that those strains could be used as a cue to promote blood vessel sprouting.
